title: @Riot: Philosophy Behind Utility Mastery Changes?

embed.description: This is a WORK IN PROGRESS POST - Patch OUT, Login DOWN ] The PBE has been updated! Continue reading for more information! ( Warning: PBE Content is tentative and iterative - what you see may not reflect what eventually gets pushed to live servers! Manage your expectations accordingly. ) !

body:
Yesterday we got some interesting Utility mastery changes on the PBE, with the Meditate 3MP/5 being replaced with +75 flat mana, and the 5% bonus max mana masteries being replaced with 1.5% missing mana regen/5.

On the one hand, this seems like a buff to supports who needed mana in the mid to late game and didn't get to build any of the major mana items due to role / money.

On the other hand, for champions that went 21/0/9, as lots of mana intensive mages in mid do, it seems like a significant nerf to their early game. 3MP/5 eclipses 75 total mana in slightly over 2 minutes, so you can expect to have less overall mana to work with during the laning phase now.

So I'm really curious to hear what the philosophy behind this change is. Is it just to standardize mana regen into a percent based model? Is it to buff those supports? Does Riot feel that mana intensive mages needed an early game nerf? Will they be compensated?

replies.body:
Our current focus with the Utility masteries is on making going deep into the tree appropriately rewarding, particularly for caster supports and more utility focused mages. As part of that we're experimenting with making Meditation (the mana regen) significantly more powerful, but putting it later in the tree so it's one of the key distinctions between deep utility and other routes. Expanded Mind (max mana) then goes earlier, as a flat bonus instead of a %, making it particularly targeted at champions that start with a really small mana pool and want an early increase. There's a definite risk that'll leave going 9 points into utility as too unrewarding and we might need to do some work on that too, first thing we want to address is getting 21+ points in utility into a better spot however.


Changes current in testing for anyone unfamiliar with them:

* Meditation: 

    Swapped position with Expanded Mind
    Now restores 1.5% missing mana every 5 seconds instead of granting 1/2/3 mana regen every 5 seconds

* Expanded Mind: 

    Swapped position with Meditation
    Now grants 25/50/75 mana instead of 2/3.5/5% maximum mana

* Inspiration: 

    Increased the experience gain every 10 seconds to 10/20, from 5/10 

* Bandit:

    Melee--Now grant 8 gold each time an enemy champion is attacked (5 seconds cooldown),  no longer grants bonus gold from kill/assist

* Intelligence: 

    Now reduces the cooldown of Activated items by 20%, from 10%

* Wanderer: 

    Bonus Movement speed changed to a flat 20, from 5% movement speed

My opinion is that the new Expanded Mind mastery should cost 1 point (and +75 mana could be reduced to +50 mana instead if applicable) instead of 3 points. It's either this or reducing the Greed mastery points from 3 to 2. There are a lot of new utility points that are "competitive" and I feel like a small amount of flat mana is lackluster. A lot of AP Supports have the conundrum of having to put 22 points in Utility or building an "imperfect" mastery page because there are too many 3-point masteries.

Meddler, why is the Spellvamp/Lifesteal Mastery still in the Utility Tree? Don't you think this is one of the most out-of-place Masteries we have, and it is simply not something supports are really looking for.

Our original goal with the most recent mastery tree revamp was to make Utility appealing to more than just supports (not to the degree it's mandatory on pretty much everyone, like the original masteries, but as a viable option). That didn't really work out, Spell vamp/Lifesteal were put there to support that goal of non support users as well however. If this current work, focused on making deep utility more appealing in general, doesn't start to show some value there that could be a good candidate for replacement at some point as a result.

tbh the thing that killed the utility tree for non-supports was switching the 21st point from  "movement speed" to "out-of-combat movement speed".

If a mage/assassin/bruiser wants "out of combat" movement speed, they will buy mobility boots. Going 21 points deep into utility isn't worth giving up all the damage they get from going 21 deep into offense. They also want COMBAT stats from their masteries, not "out of combat" stats.

If you want utility to be viable on non-supports, switch the 21st point to back to how it was, "in-combat AND out-of-combat movement speed", otherwise simply known as "movement speed".

Context: season 3 I went 21 deep into utility on Udyr. When you switched it to "out of combat movespeed" in season 4 I stopped.

I'd really like to see the spell vamp and lifesteal master trade places with that mastery in the offense tree that increases dmg dealt by your allies every time you hit them. I think that'd be much more desirable on supports.

It seems like that was part of the original purpose (they were put in opposite trees to support a variety of masteries amongst different roles) but if they do move the spell vamp, that's the logical swap, and making it a "little" stronger too :)

yeah, but when players are looking to make masteries, they are looking for efficiency, not exactly variety.

putting SV and LS deep in the support tree makes it way too costly to take it on champs that could actually utilize it. And it serves really no purpose on anyone that can afford it cuz they won't deal enough dmg to benefit from the low values.

If riot wants variety in masteries, they should make more mastery options in the rank 1 and rank 2 positions so that you can have multiple combos with just 9 points while making 21 points in any given tree less variety simply because when you invest that many points in a tree, yer looking for optimization.

Most of the champs who would want spellvamp in the first place are manaless, but to get through the utility tree, they're forced to take weak masteries because they don't use mana.  Unfortunately it doesn't seem Riot's new changes are addressing this, as 1.5% movespeed for 3 mastery points is still pretty weak.

In fact, mana masteries are maybe the only masteries in the game that champs may get absolutely zero value from - could Riot maybe take a look at replacing them with more generally attractive options and pushing the mana help to base values or itemization?
A couple of champs get away with 21 in Utility and still deal enough damage to make Vampirism worth it. Especially poke-based supports and Udyr.

Very true, except for one thing, More mana is not just good for more damage? Though it IS, I like the idea of my lulu, nami or even Anirva support having more mana. To be honest, Anirva mid could probably still benefit from having more Utility than pure damage, it'll hurt her somewhere, but her poke and range make up for it, and that fully upgraded E :D

Now you want to make it even harder for her? Please say you're gonna give her some TLC.

You can´t push against them, because your mana costs are so insanely high. And since most of them even have some mobility, they can get away with pushing a lot. If Lux steps over the middle of the lane, she is basicly dead if the jungler decides to show.
She already has to buy Athenes and still has mana problems. She can´t even decide to pick up a Morello´s. She is very unflexible, and she is not even good at what she does. Ziggs is just better at everything, exept a shield.

Also, 75 extra mana is just one extra spell compared to being able to cast another spell a couple seconds earlier, and not even that for Lux, considering how high the cost on Singularity is (hint hint, please reduce that cost). Being able to cast spells sooner vs being able to cast one extra spell is potentially a life or death situation early on.

Also, I'm not going going to dig deeper into utility when I still need my damage output.

Most champions will have 300+ mana with the new +75 mana. If we use a champ with 50% of their max mana, they would regen 2.25 every 5 seconds, which only increases with each level, sounds like this is a mana regen buff to me.
It is, but they moved the mana regen up so high that you need to put 12 points into utility to get it. And then 3 more points to actually get the mana regen. So no more 21/0/9.

Exactly. So if you go for 21 points in utility, you'll have more mana in lane and more mana regen throughout the game.

But most mid and top mages need 21 points in offense. Now they have to choose between having more mana in lane, but less damage scaling, or being more pinched for mana and keeping the same damage. To make matters worse, because the new mana regen mastery is percent based, it doesn't really become that powerful until the mid-late game, by which time any mages who needed them have already built their mana items.

I think utility based Lissandra Jungle can become viable with those change (with 9/0/21). As well as other mages jungle, because what they lack the most is mana regen on core item (magus enchant). That's good.

Vampirism masteries may just need a little bit more power, 1.5/3/4.5 like the quint runes maybe? :)

It's difficult for me to say since I usually play my mages 21/9/0 instead of 21/0/9. I usually prefer the defenses and dueling power early rather than having more mana. 

But this will definitely be a buff to supports. More so with poke and utility support rather than tank supports.
Their Balance Philosophy on this subject is "Passive laning is unfun, and strategic diversity means only strategies we think are fun should be allowed."
